body: The UK Faculty for Homeless and Inclusion Health’s annual symposium on health, homelessness and multiple exclusion takes place in London on Wednesday 2nd and Thursday 3rd March 2016.
The symposium is developed by Pathway (the homeless health charity) and the Faculty for Homeless and Inclusion Health with support from the Health Foundation, NHS England and partners.
This is the fourth symposium and study days bringing together the latest in evidence and best practice from around Europe in health and public services.
title: Homeless and Inclusion Health: Annual International Symposium & Study Days

body: One day conference in association with HSCIC for Information Security and Governance professionals.
use promo code HSCIC30 to get the HSCIC cost price place
title: THINK™Healthcare

body: Almost everybody in NHS commissioning is now working for a new organisation – whether NHS England, a CCG, a CSU or another body supporting commissioners. For some this will feel like a new name plate on the door, others will already be experiencing fundamental changes in decision-making processes in an uncertain and ambiguous environment.

70% of change programmes fail. Successful change leaders are able to adapt to changing circumstances and to bring their teams with them. This requires sound judgement, decision-making skills in an uncertain environment, personal resilience and an ability to understand and support others at different stages of change.

This one-day workshop is for managers undergoing and supporting staff through change programmes. The content explores the merits of different approaches to implementing change and an understanding of the role and skills of an effective change agent. The workshop allows delegates to consider their own impact and emotions, and equips them the tools needed to facilitate and implement change.
Delivered by a mix of presentation, group work, real-life case studies and simulation, the workshop will enable you to:
Understand a range of approaches and choose the one best suited to your context
Use effective change management tools to facilitate implementation
Consider ways to navigate successfully through uncertainty
Understand the role of organisational politics play in the change process and how to develop political expertise
Use the correct language to facilitate successful change
Monitor and review the change process to help overcome obstacles and resistance
Build personal resilience to deal with the pressure of change.

The workshop is led by PCC’s expert facilitators and will bring a wealth of experience of managing and navigating change from a variety of organisations in the public and private sector and a deep understanding of the NHS commissioning environment.
title: Successful change agents

body: This practical NHS Endoscopy seminar is your opportunity to step away from your daily challenges and dedicate a time to think clearly about your capacity and demand concerns and how to tackle these mounting service pressures head on. Review your service and go back to your trust with the tools to design and implement a system to maximise capacity and manage increasing demand. Don’t miss out on valuable, best practice advice.
title: Managing Capacity and Demand in Endoscopy Services
Priorities for the future of health and social care in Wales

body: This course will take you step by step through the business and service requirements your radiology service needs to fulfil in order to be commissioned and meet the needs of your CCG, patient and trust. From financial planning, through to service reviews; identify how you can bring together data and performance measurements and pair them with effective marketing techniques to showcase your service delivery.
title: Best Practice Financial Planning for Radiology Services

body: Attend this practical interactive workshop to examine strategies to futureproof your clinical coding team, explore ways to engage with clinicians and deliver an efficient clinical coding service. This unique clinical coding seminar will enable you to tackle your workforce challenges, develop your staffing strategies, build your toolbox and take away cost effective solutions to your current dilemmas.
title: Designing your Cost Effective Clinical Coding Workforce Strategy
NHS Health Check Conference 2016: Getting Serious About Prevention
Innovative contracting for new care models

body: The Five Year Forward View is the vision to provide more power to patients, deliver better outcomes and make the NHS more efficient with greater integration at its core. With increased demand inevitable, removing the barriers and boundaries of traditional practice and embracing new models of working are seen as the drivers to sustaining the NHS into the future. NHS England are committed to the idea that technology and data are key to implementing the necessary changes and have a major part to play in the new ways of delivering care.
A digitally enabled NHS will transform how it operates and generate significant benefits such as improved patient experience, supported clinical interactions and enhanced administrative processes.
title: Digital Healthcare Revolution: Harnessing NHS Technology

body: This course seeks to provide students with an understanding of non-technical skills vital in multidisciplinary healthcare simulation teaching and learning. This is ideal for people involved in the delivery of simulated teaching who want to understand the learning process of their students and how to maximise the impact of their work on subsequent healthcare practice. Topics include stress and fatigue, communication strategies,  leadership and the importance of task management- all directly related to simulation practice.
title: Non-technical skills for multidisciplinary healthcare simulation

body: This practical NHS Endoscopy seminar is your opportunity to step away from your daily challenges and dedicate a time to think clearly about your capacity and demand concerns and how to tackle these mounting service pressures head on. Review your service and go back to your trust with the tools to design and implement a system to maximise capacity and manage increasing demand. Don’t miss out on valuable, best practice advice.
title: Managing Capacity and Demand in Endoscopy Services

body: Capacity in NHS ophthalmology services continues to be a huge challenge. This event offers you the opportunity to take just one day out and learn from how other services from around the UK are innovating to cope.
title: Maximising Capacity in your Ophthalmology Service

body: By focusing on recent inquiries and identifying the outcomes, this dedicated day will equip you with the tools and insight to comply with CQC requirements and meet patient complaints with understanding. By moving away from timeliness, the course will focus on evidence based communication skills and enable you to address outcomes and quality.
title: Effective Complaints Handling

body: Designed specifically for Ophthalmology Consultants, Nurses and Service Managers, this one day course will delve into the detail of a successful nurse-led IVT injection service model. Participants will leave having gained invaluable insights into how to build the business case, overcome the barriers to implementation, achieve internal support and innovate in service delivery.
title: A Practical Guide to Implementing a Nurse-Led Intravitreal Injection Service

body: If you want to fully understand the most recent NHS England guidance on bringing together the key work streams relating to the Five Year Forward View, Digital Roadmaps, New Models of Care, and Capitated Payment Systems, don’t miss this intensive learning day. Our seminar leader, David Stone, Principal Consultant, Kaleidoscope Consultants Ltd, will demystify the Personalised Health and Care 2020: A Framework for Action and demonstrate the interlinking strategies you need to implement in your organisation.
title: Information Governance for Integrated Health and Social Care

body: A half day training including presentations, practical computer sessions & discussions on how to apply for research approvals using the IRAS system

The Integrated Research Approvals System (IRAS) is now the only mechanism by which all applications to NHS research ethics committees are handled (as well most of the other main research approvals, including R&D and MHRA). Researchers who have in past applied for research approvals (ethics, R&D etc) but need a refresher, or who intend to apply for the first time, will benefit from this course.
title: Applying for Research Approvals in Lothian - Using IRAS
The future for primary care in Greater Manchester

body: Clinical trials incorporate the language of business; milestone, deliverables, resources, stakeholders and management.
This seminar will explore the concept that business knowledge and practice can be superimposed onto the process of planning and running clinical trials.
title: Clinical Trials – Can a Business Model be applied?

body: This 5 day course is designed to equip individuals, who have a basic understanding of cost effectiveness analysis, with the skills required to build 2 types of decision analytic cost effectiveness models; decision trees and Markov models.

Designed and delivered by internationally recognised experts in cost effectiveness analyses, the course will combine focused pedagogic sessions with practical exercises to provide participants with hands-on experience of building the most commonly used types of cost effectiveness models, undertaking deterministic and probabilistic sensitivity analyses, Value of Information Analyses and producing a range of outputs to meet the requirements of reimbursement authorities in the Europe, North America and Australasia.

The course is suitable for postgraduate students, health professionals, analysts and post-doctoral researchers working in academia, public health systems, pharmaceutical and device manufacturers, as well as commercial research organizations. Teaching assistants and additional tutors will be present to support participants in the applied exercise sessions.

Course participants will be provided with a course handbook and certificate of completion. In addition, participants will be provided with MS Excel macros for implementing many of the techniques taught in the course.
title: Introduction to Cost Effectiveness Modelling

body: We are pleased to announce that the British Society of Audiology Annual Conference, entitled Transforming Knowledge to Sound Practice will be taking place on 25th – 27th April 2016 at the Ricoh Arena in Coventry.

The British Society of Audiology Annual Conference continues to be one of the leading UK scientific forums to bring together clinicians and researchers who have an interest in hearing, tinnitus and balance.
The 2016 programme has undergone a revamp. Day 1 will focus on basic science, with a morning of dedicated poster time. Days 2 and 3 cover translational and clinical science.
Important Dates

. This event is

body: The aims of this module are to provide students with 1. An understanding of the process for creating an effect scenario that can be

used in simulation training and 2. Knowledge of the available technologies and how to ‘drive’ the technology. Additionally students on this module will explore all roles within the simulation faculty and how they contribute to the fidelity of multidisciplinary health care simulation as well as the principles of debriefing a simulation scenario. Ideal for those who lead or teach on a simulation programme of any kind.
title: Development and debriefing of multidisciplinary healthcare simulation scenarios

body: The End of Life Care: Collaboration, Compassion, Choice conference will help you to develop a greater understanding of how end of life care is going to be delivered in England over the next five years. The programme will feature an overview of the latest policy and guidance from organisations such as NHS England and NICE, as well as further discussion around implementation and plans for the future. This will be supplemented by practical sessions which are designed to be transferable, encouraging adoption across different teams and organisations. Open Forum Events are delighted to be gaining a reputation for “truly inspirational” health and social care conferences. Our delegates are telling us that they leave our events with “new ideas and approaches” they can actually apply within their own organisations.
title: End of Life Care: Collaboration, Compassion, Choice

body: This module is aimed at general practitioners and practice nurses working in the community who wish to develop competencies in the management of gynaecological disorders to an advanced level. Some prior knowledge of basic community gynaecology and sexual health is required before undertaking this course, which can be taken as an entire MSc module or as three stand alone CPD days. Each day has a distinct theme so you can choose those most relevant to your professional requirements.
title: Management of Gynaecology in the Community
Priorities for palliative and end of life care policy: choice, quality and integration

body: Despite harmonisation of clinical trial of medicines and Good Clinical Practice in Europe, a multi-centre international trial can present unique challenges. These range from the obvious – language, and cultural matters to data management and security, resources, time differences, standardisation of clinical practice and access internationally validated questionnaires.
This seminar will outline the management challenges encountered and the lessons learned.
title: The Challenges of Managing European Clinical Trials

body: The North and South London Branches of the Infection Prevention Society (IPS) would like to invite you to attend their 2016 annual conference on Thursday 14th April 2016 at the Imperial College in London.

This day will be of interest to infection prevention and control practitioners, link nurses, mental health nurses, IV practitioners, district nurses, care homes and student nurses. This list does not exclude any other healthcare professional with an interest in preventing and controlling infection.

Also on offer is access to a large exhibition with a wide range of companies bringing new and innovative products to the market. This event offers valuable learning and an ideal opportunity to socialise with like-minded colleagues and discuss the issues you face on a daily basis.
Registration will open at 8:45am, with the first session starting at 9:30am. The day will finish at 3:55pm and lunch and refreshments will be provided.
All 70 free IPS member and link nurse places are now fully booked however members can still attend at the non-member rate of £40.
To secure your place please follow this link
title: IPS London Branches Conference – ‘What’s left in the tool kit?’

body: A half day training including presentations, practical computer sessions & discussions on how to apply for research approvals using the IRAS system

The Integrated Research Approvals System (IRAS) is now the only mechanism by which all applications to NHS research ethics committees are handled (as well most of the other main research approvals, including R&D and MHRA). Researchers who have in past applied for research approvals (ethics, R&D etc) but need a refresher, or who intend to apply for the first time, will benefit from this course.

body: This one-day course aims to provide an overview of the design, data collection, analysis, and reporting considerations associated with successful incorporation of PROMs in clinical trials. It’s aimed at Chief and Principal Investigators, trial managers, clinical researchers, and academics. In this course, you’ll learn to:
The course is taught by Prof Mel Calvert, Dr Thomas Keeley, and Dr Derek Kyte from the University of Birmingham.
title: Successfully Incorporating Patient-Reported Outcome Measures (PROMs) in Clinical Trials

body: This interactive, discussion-focussed event gives you the opportunity to meet and network with other Counselling Psychologists who are facing the same issues as you. With a mix of presentations and interactive workshops, this is a great opportunity for you to find out how you can take responsibility for enhancing your skills and experience and move forward in your career. You’ll leave with a host of useful strategies to enhance both your own practice and your career in the NHS, as well as practical advice for those of you looking to develop your private practice and pursue other career avenues.
Book on or before 29th January and NHS and public sector attendees will pay just £149 plus VAT.
title: Counselling Psychologists National Networking Forum

body: This one-day introductory course aims to provide an overview of the practical considerations associated with collecting Patient-Reported Outcome Measures (PROMs) in clinical trials. It’s aimed at research nurses, data managers, and study co-ordinators. In this course, you’ll learn to:
• understand the different types of PROMs and how/when they should be administered
• assist patients completing PROMs and answer common patient questions
• prevent/manage missing data and scoring errors
• support patients in answering sensitive PROM questions
• manage ‘PRO Alerts’ and patient distress
• collect PROM data in different patient groups and settings
The course is taught by Prof Mel Calvert, Dr Thomas Keeley, and Dr Derek Kyte from the University of Birmingham.
title: Collecting Patient-Reported Outcome Measures (PROMs) in Clinical Trials

body: This interactive day gives IAPT service managers, clinical psychologists, high intensity and CBT therapists and PWPs the opportunity to find out how to overcome the challenges of setting up and maintaining an IAPT LTC service that delivers good clinical and patient experience outcomes. With case studies from the IAPT LTC pathfinder sites, as well as an update on the IAPT LTC pathfinder data evaluation from the IAPT LTC evaluation agency, you’ll leave with a wealth of practical ideas for moving your LTC service forward.
Book on or before 29th January and NHS and public sector attendees will pay just £149 plus VAT.
title: IAPT for Long Term Conditions National Networking Forum

body: Day 1. An introduction to systematic reviews
The day will include the following topics:
What are systematic reviews and why are they important?
Different types of systematic reviews (e.g. of qualitative and quantitative studies)
Building blocks of a systematic review
i) how to  develop a review question
ii) how to  develop inclusion and exclusion criteria
iii) how to  develop a search strategy
iv) applying inclusion and exclusion criteria
v) quality appraisal
vi) data extraction and recording processes
The day will be a mix of lectures (knowledge building) and group work (skill building)
Day 2.  Analysing studies for a systematic review
Morning: analysing quantitative studies (randomised controlled trials) [non-experimental designs are not included in this course]
This is a basic level course, and not intended to give in-depth statistical advice or teaching. It is more of an overview of the range of techniques, and when to use them.
Introduction to analytical methods for quantitative experimental studies (i.e. RCTs, quasi-RCTs, controlled studies)
Understanding and dealing with heterogeneity
Meta-analysis
Subgroup analysis
Narrative analysis
Drawing conclusions
Making recommendations for research and practice.
The session will draw on a Cochrane Systematic review by the lecturer:
Cranberries for preventing urinary tract infections
Afternoon session: analysis of qualitative studies (e.g. focus group and interview studies)

The aim of this session is to introduce two of the main analytical techniques used in synthesising  qualitative studies (thematic analysis and meta-ethnography). Both are relatively technical so this will be an overview session rather than providing everyskill neeeded to perform such an analysis. However, participants will have an opportunity to undertake a thematic analysis.
Introduction to qualitative synthesis
Thematic synthesis: what is it and how to do it
Meta-ethnography: what it is and how to do it
Quality appraisal of qualitative studies
Drawing conclusions
Making recommendations for research and practice.
title: How to Undertake a Systematic Review

body: Since the publication of the National Cancer Survivorship Initiative “Visioning” paper in 2010, the momentum behind improving             services for patients living with and beyond cancer has increased exponentially. The challenge for the next few years is to facilitate implementation of these innovations into mainstream cancer services. In April 2014, The Christie, Macmillan Cancer Support and University of Salford joined forces to hold a conference discussing and debating the challenges, issues and controversies related to an increasing population of cancer survivors. Join us on 11th March 2016 where we will pick up the discussions.
Topics which will be discussed :
title: The Changing Prospects for Cancer –‘A Good Survival’

body: A new era for mental health care is on the horizon… Mental Health: Moving Forwards – The Five Year Plan will explore how the new national strategy for mental health services can drive action so that people across all ages can get the right help at the right time.

For the first time NHS England are publishing a five year strategy for mental health services to develop a new culture and new ways of working. Prevention, service quality and integration are at its core. The Five Year Forward View has provided a shared vision about what mental health care should like, now the vision needs to become reality.

The clear strategic themes are centred on prevention, access, quality and integration. These themes will drive system transformation and help to establish a framework with measureable objectives. The Five Year Forward View Mental Health Taskforce recognises that the NHS alone cannot transform mental health services – it is ‘everyone’s business’. If we are to improve the experience of care both in and out of NHS settings then integration, access and co-production of services will be vital. So how do we do it?
title: Mental Health: Moving Forwards – The Five Year Plan
Primary care and the developing role of the GP

body: This event will get you off the ground by sharing different pathways that have been developed and established, how the referral links work and what models have been implemented effectively. By sharing the experience of different size organisations with varying demographics and health infrastructures you will be able to identify with the drivers and parameters that are needed in your pathway.
title: Cancer of Unknown Primary Pathway Development

body: Take one day out to find out the answer to ‘what else you should be doing?’ If you have an established structure and are now looking to substantiate your service and cut down on diagnostic time, this forward looking day will share the working models at Portsmouth NHS Trust where flow has been improved and every activity accounted for.
title: How to Set up and Deliver Nurse Led Acute Oncology

body: For many researchers “to get ethics” is their main focus and driver within the approval process. As a researcher, trial manager and alternate Vice-Chair of an Ethics Committee I will impart some of the knowledge I have learnt, implemented and received from both sides of the committee table.
title: The Only Way is Ethics – Ethics Committee Submission: Document Preparation
Diagnosis and Management of Airways Disease

body: This half day workshop is directed at those with no, or only very limited knowledge of statistics who require a better understanding of how statistics can be used to describe and summarise data.
Delivered by Dr David Chinn, Senior Research Advisor and R&D Coordinator, NHS Fife; Dr Chinn is not a statistician but an epidemiologist with a working knowledge of stats.
The level of presentation is very basic and examples will be used throughout to illustrate the procedures and concepts.
title: Statistics for the Terrified (An Introduction to Statistics)

body: The latest in our series of events designed specifically for PWPs and Senior PWPs, this is an interactive training day, developed and brought to you in association with the University of East Anglia. Choose from three focussed PWP training workshops on Step 2 interventions for Social Anxiety, Older People and Long Term Conditions that offer you the opportunity to advance your skills and develop specialisations.
Book on or before 29th January and NHS and public sector attendees will pay just £149 plus VAT.
title: PWP Clinical Skills Training Day

body: Attend this interactive NHS Nuclear Medicine seminar to share cost effective ideas to develop your workforce, meet capacity and demand challenges and improve patient experience. This day has been specifically designed for NHS teams working within Clinical Imaging, Medical Physics, Radiology and Nuclear Medicine departments.
title: Driving Forward your Nuclear Medicine Service

body: Hear the latest information to progress your data accuracy, engagement and digital strategies at SBK’s 8th Annual Clinical Coding Conference. Bring your knowledge right up to date with presentations that include real solutions to issues facing NHS Clinical Coders. The key themes for the day are >> Strategies to Ensure Data Accuracy in Clinical Coding >> Understanding the wider use of clinically coded data >> Coding in the digital age.
title: Clinical Coding Update 2016

body: For primary care practitioners looking to improve skills and knowledge around hypertension management.

body: The Queen’s Nursing Institute’s Homeless Health Programme’s goal is to help create the best possible healthcare for the homeless, and it contributes by helping community nurses to improve their learning and practice with homeless patients.

On Wednesday January 27th 2016, the programme will be holding a free event for health professionals and commissioners about ‘Improving Mental Healthcare for People Who are Homeless’. The one-day workshop features speakers Thea Stein, Chief Executive of Leeds Community NHS Trust, Cheryl Kipping, Dual Diagnosis Lead Nurse at South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust and Dr Alice Haynes, Senior Research and Policy Lead at the NSPCC.
The event comes at a time of great challenge to mental health services, as evidenced today by the King's Fund:
http://www.kingsfund.org.uk/publications/mental-health-under-pressure

The QNI event will be held at the Deafblind UK National Conference Centre in Peterborough and will be a rewarding day for anyone interested in improving the quality of mental healthcare for people who are homeless in their area.

If you would like to attend or to find out more about the event please email lauren.knight@qni.org.uk or visit the Eventbrite page at https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/improving-mental-healthcare-for-people-who-are-homeless-tickets-19204210310
title: Improving mental healthcare for people who are homeless

Unique booking code - NET200

body: PIF are delighted to announce that bookings are now open for the 'Communicating Risk in Health Information' event on Tuesday 26 January 2016, to be held in London.

Risks and statistics are an essential part of patient information. What is a person’s risk of developing a particular condition in their lifetime, or of having a certain symptom? What is the chance of a treatment or procedure working? What is the risk of getting different side-effects? And can people change these risk factors?

However, many patients are unable to comprehend basic statistics, never mind navigate their way through the reams of data that may come with health information comparing treatment options. As information and support professionals, your job is to make sure you can guide patients through the minefield of data and figures to help them feel confident in making their own decisions.

This one day event will: look at the challenges many patients experience when trying to understand risk; hear from experts in the field of communicating risk; and share case studies from health information professionals who have addressed this in their work.

The event will close with a practical group session that allows delegates to discuss the key challenges they face and how they can apply the findings or recommendations from the presentations in their work.
Please get in touch now for more information or to secure your place at:
or email claire.murray@pifonline.org.uk
title: Communicating Risk in Health Information
SROI Practitioner Training
